title: Translating Predictive Coding Into Perceptual Control
summary:
Key ideas:
- The free energy principle says that all life is driven by the imperative to reduce the gulf between expectations and sensory inputs.
- Perceptual control theory and free energy/predictive coding are fundamentally the same paradigm.
- The author provides a glossary to help understand the concepts of prediction, expectation, set point, reference level, prediction error, surprise, active inference, and behavior as control of perception.
- Perceptual control theory uses more intuitive terms than free energy/predictive coding, which can be confusing.

Key learnings:
- Free energy/predictive coding grew out of an account of world-modeling, while perceptual control theory explains movement, motivation, and desire.
- FE/PC terminology should be kept, but PCT terminology can be taught as a learning aid.

Key questions:
- How come everyone uses the FE/PC formulation instead of the PCT formulation since PCT has more advantages?
- Is Powers' explanation of world-modeling the same as FE/PC?
- Could it be possible to construct a PCT look at world-modeling?
